Award.AwardTitle: The Kinetics of Interacting Particle Systems: Theory and Numerical Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall objective of this research is to develop accurate modeling and simulation for a series of diverse phenomena of fundamental scientific interest, at the edge of various technological developments such as hot-electron transport in semiconductor devices, nano structures for the solar generation of hydrogen, reacting molecular mixtures, and evolution of plasmas in fusion models. Modeling and simulation will be based on data obtained by accurate crystallographic calculations, taking into account atomistic corrections, the presence of rough media, etc. Many of the techniques to be developed are pertinent also to exciting new applications in biological and social sciences. They include modeling of self-organized flows in "particle" swarms like birds or fish, emerging consensus in population dynamics, multi-agent information transfer, and social information dynamics in Internet, to name a few.

These research goals comprise a broad program in the development of analytical and numerical tools associated with statistical transport equations at the core of applied mathematics in probability, statistics, and physics. They concern the modeling of complex interactions systems yielding kinetic frameworks associated to Markovian processes of birth-death dynamics. Such statistical approaches lead to nonlinear integro-differential systems of equations of collisional Boltzmann or Smolukowski type. Many of these models appear in the collisional theory of semi-classical transport for short and long range interactions models that describe self-consistent phenomena at nano and mesoscales. More recently, collisional of birth-death processes have been appearing in the modeling of self organized swarm flows in social interactions and flocking dynamics, formation of networks, and queuing in supply chains. New tools from non-linear analysis as well as new computational strategies will be developed to address long time behavior, stability and decay rates to stationary modes, as well as qualitative behavior of numerical solutions and optimal computational strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This funded project covered five major areas in Applied Mathematics, focusing on different aspects of rigorous applied analysis and numerical approximations to non-linear dynamics associated to statistical flow or kinetic modeling. These models apply to areas ranging from interactive particle systems in multi-agents in the description of imperfect information theory and opinion dynamics, swarming and flocking models, to the statistical theory of interacting rarefied neutral or charge (Coulomb) gases that model plasma dynamics, as well as in the emerging area of interface reacting models in PhotoElectroChemical (PEC) solar cell technology.  Specific applications of the later range from very high altitude flights and collisional plasmas in rarefied regimes such of the ionosphere, kinetic chemical reaction and dynamics and material science in nanotechnology in semiconductor design. In addition, numerical methods developed by the PI and collaborators will make an impact in the design of flying objects in rarefied gas environments as well as in semiconductor and solar cell design.

This project partially funded seven graduate students, of whom; five of them got their PhD degree during the Spring 2017 to Spring 2017 period. Three of these students graduated from the Computational Science, Engineering and Mathematics program. Two of the are working in companies, Schlumberger, Houston, and JPMorgan, NYC, while the third one is under a postdoctoral appointment at the computational electronics group at the Technical University in Vienna. Two female students graduated from the Mathematics program and the currently have postdoctoral appointments at the University of Pennsylvania and Brown University.

During this funded period, the PI gave thirty presentations at national and international workshops and conferences, two distinguished lectures, The SIAM-AWM Sonia Kowalevski lecture award in July 2014 and the invited SIAM-AMS plenary lecture at the Joint Mathematics Meetings in January 2017. She also delivered sixteen lectures or colloquia at major academic institutions worldwide.  In addition she organized or co-organized twelve workshops and conference.

The PI directs the Applied Mathematics Group (AMG) one of the research groups at the Institute of Computational Science and Engineering  (ICES) at the University of Texas at Austin.

The PI collaborates with individuals from Physics and chemistry and computational Mathematicians and Physicists at Los Alamos National Laboratories as well as Oak Ridge National Laboratory in a project consisting in runaway electron avoidance and mitigation in Tokamaks partially funded by the Department of Energy to support the international ITER effort.
